Situation1: They notice their parents appear more stressed and tired than usual.
Expectation2: Perform assigned physical tasks and material handling efficiently.
Situation2: The supervisor has asked you to move a stack of unused materials to a different storage area sometime before the end of the day.
Story: I noticed the deep lines on my mother’s face this morning, the way she lingered over her tea, eyes distant. Dad barely touched his breakfast. I wanted to sit with them, ask what was wrong, offer comfort, but my shift started early. At the site, sweat already stung my eyes as I hauled bricks. My supervisor caught me on my way to grab water. “Move those unused tiles to the back lot before you clock out,” he said, voice clipped. I nodded, feeling the weight of the task. The pile was heavy, and the day was already long. My phone buzzed in my pocket—Mom’s name on the screen. I imagined her needing to talk, maybe just to hear my voice. But the stack of tiles loomed, and the supervisor’s words echoed in my mind. I stood there, torn, the ache in my arms matched by the ache in my chest, unsure which duty to answer first.
